newsitem.title: USA: Miami may tax commuters to help close deficit.
newsitem.headline: Miami may tax commuters to help close deficit.

text.p: The Miami city commission has agreed to consider a proposal by Mayor Jo Carollo to impose a $10 per month "commuter fee" on people who work but don't live in the city.
In a unanimous vote on Thursday, the commission asked the city attorney to investigate whether a commuter tax is feasible and how it could be collected.
Several U.S. cities, including New York, Kansas City and Philadelphia levy taxes on non-residents who commute into the cities to work to help pay for city roads, trash collection and police services.

A $10 monthly commuter tax in Miami would raise an estimated $72 million a year in non-resident taxes, based on the assumption that about 600,000 people commute to Miami on weekdays. But a commuter tax proposal is also likely to be opposed by businesses.
The city commission met Thursday to try and find ways to reduce a $68 million budget deficit.
